content.content: In the United States, about 7.6% of pregnancy-related deaths are from Preeclampsia, Eclampsia and complications from these conditions.[^24] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/P9GxHQzwIzk __Preeclampsia is new high blood pressure, protein in the urine, and/or other symptoms found at or more than 20 weeks of pregnancy and less than 4 weeks after delivery.__[^24][^25][^26][^27][^28][^29] ## Preeclampsia: - Blood pressure greater than or equal to 140/90 mmHg - Protein in the urine and/or dark urine - Upper belly pain under the ribs - Nausea &/or vomiting after the middle of pregnancy - Shortness of breath, panting, or wheezing - Chest pain behind the breastbone - Headache not getting better after pain medication - Confusion, dizziness, or acting strangely - Seeing spots, flashes, blurring, and/or not seeing in one eye or both - Bleeding from gums, nose, eyes and/or in urine or bowel movements - Very pale or yellow skin, fever, and/or weakness ## Severe Preeclampsia:[^24][^25][^26][^27][^28][^29] - Blood pressure greater than or equal to 160/110 mmHg - Protein in the urine or dark urine - Upper belly pain under the ribs - Nausea &/or vomiting after the middle of pregnancy - Very short of breath, wheezing, &/or coughing up blood  - Chest pain behind the breastbone - Confusion, dizziness, or acting strangely - Headache not getting better after pain medication - Seeing spots, flashes, blurring, and/or not seeing in one eye or both - Bleeding from gums, nose, eyes and/or in urine or bowel movements - Very pale or yellow skin, fever and/or weakness - Very small amount of urine  ## Eclampsia:[^24][^25][^26][^27][^28][^29] - Seizures - Blood pressure greater than or equal to 140/90 mmHg - Coma - Protein in the urine Embedded content: https://youtu.be/dyh46iIcmkQ __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about your loved one.__ [The Hospital Plan of Care form](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/POC-Blank-April-19.pdf "The Hospital Plan of Care form") [Guide to Medical Care at a Distance](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Guide-to-Medical-Care-at-a-Distance.pdf "Guide to Medical Care at a Distance") [Preeclampsia information from the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/000898.htm) [Preeclampsia Information from the Preeclampsia Foundation](http://www.preeclampsia.org/health-information/faqs) [^24]: Division of Reproductive Health. Pregnancy mortality surveillance system. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) website. http://www.cdc.gov/reproductivehealth/maternalinfanthealth/pmss.html. Updated January 21, 2016. Accessed February 2, 2016. [^25]: The Preeclampsia Foundation. 7 symptoms every pregnant woman should know [Video]. YouTube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P9GxHQzwIzk&list=LL31GglpqkW9B1NW8eHUZ-CA&index=3. Published May 6, 2014. Accessed January 30, 2016. [^26]: Sibai BM. Diagnosis and management of gestational hypertension and preeclampsia. Obstet Gynecol 2003;102(1):181-192. doi:10.1016/S0029-7844(03)00475-7. http://utilis.net/Morning%20Topics/Obstetrics/Sibai-GHTN.pdf. Accessed January 30, 2016. [^27]: Sibai BM, Stella CL. Diagnosis and management of atypical preeclampsia- eclampsia. Am J Obstet Gynecol 2009;200:481.e1-481.e7. http://data5.blog.de/media/028/3852028_804aa10515_d.pdf. Accessed January 28, 2016. [^28]: Roberts JM, August PA, Bakris G, Barton JR, Bernstein IM, Druzin M, et al. Hypertension in pregnancy. ACOG Task Force on Hypertension in Pregnancy 2013. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Washington, D.C. http://www.acog.org/Resources-And-Publications/Task-Force-and-Work-Group-Reports/Hypertension-in-Pregnancy. Accessed January 28, 2016. [^29]: Sibai BM. Etiology and management of postpartum hypertension-preclampsia. Am J Obstet Gynecol 2012;206(6):470-475. http://www.ajog.org/article/S0002-9378(11)01155-0/fulltext. Accessed January 30, 2016.
